section_title: Partial hip resurfacing (Evidence: pg no: 24, L857)
names: Partial hip resurfacing (Evidence: pg no: 24, L857)
Partial hip resurfacing of the femoral head (Evidence: pg no: 24, L858)
description: Partial hip resurfacing of the femoral head is considered medically necessary when ALL of the following criteria are met. (Evidence: pg no: 24, L858-L859)
scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

documentation: Osteonecrosis of the femoral head (less than 50% involvement) with subchondral collapse (Evidence: pg no: 24, L860)
Imaging evidence of significant joint destruction and cartilage loss, defined as Tönnis grade 3, modified Outerbridge grade III – IV, or Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 – 4 (Evidence: pg no: 24, L861-L862)
Limited range of motion, antalgic gait and disabling pain of at least 3 months' duration (Evidence: pg no: 24, L863)
Pain with passive internal or external rotation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L864)
Failure of at least 3 months of non-surgical conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 24, L865-L866)
Functional limitation secondary to hip pathology which interferes with the ability to perform age-appropriate daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 25, L868-L869)

exclusions: Indications for partial hip resurfacing other than those addressed in this guideline are considered not medically necessary (Evidence: pg no: 26, L937-L938)
